Award.AwardTitle: Layerless Additive Manufacturing of 3D Objects with Wide Solid Cross Sections

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing, also known as three-dimensional (3D) printing, is a class of manufacturing technologies that make 3D objects by accumulating rather than removing material (e.g. machining). Most current additive manufacturing technologies accumulate material in a layer-by-layer process. Recently, layerless additive manufacturing techniques based on vat processing have been suggested. Advantages include faster processing speed, smoother surfaces and better part quality using layerless techniques. However, processing speed and part quality are critical challenges for producing parts with relatively wide solid cross sections. This award supports fundamental research to provide new knowledge for layerless additive manufacturing of arbitrary 3D objects with wide solid cross sections. The establishment of a fast, layerless additive manufacturing process would enable the production of part shapes and sizes beyond trusses or shells. The research involves multiple disciplines of physics, surface science, microfluidics and manufacturing technology and will contribute new knowledge to advanced manufacturing. The research will have significant impact on a large number of minority students and enhance STEM education.

Continuous Liquid Interface Production is a layerless additive manufacturing technology based on vat photopolymerization that can achieve build speeds 25 to 100 times faster than layer-by-layer photopolymerization. However, the horizontal distance over which the replenishment polymer can travel before polymerization occurs is limited, which prohibits printing of parts with large cross-sections. This grant will establish a fundamental understanding of the manufacturing process by investigating the resin flow-curing dynamics. The research team will perform liquid-gel-solid multi-phase modeling to understand the resin flow, explore new window designs to accelerate resin replenishment, and establish new light delivery strategies to coordinate resin flow and curing processes. This research will test the hypothesis that the integration of a textured window and a gradient light delivery strategy will enable continuous printing of arbitrary objects with wide solid cross sections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes- Intellectual merits:

This project established the fundamental knowledge of resin flow-curing dynamics and liquid-gel-solid multiphysics in continuous projection stereolithography process, through finite element modeling and experimental studies.  Novel window surface textures were developed, and it is found that the radial groove texture and air-diffusion channel texture were effective for oxygen diffusion and resin replenishment during the continuous printing process. The knowledge of window surface texture design contributes to the development of projection stereolithography based 3D printers with higher reliability and larger printing areas. Besides, a gradient light video projection technique was explored in this work, and it is found that this novel curing strategy significantly improved the solidness and the surface quality of the printed parts.  This finding established the critical knowledge for the light energy control and video planning in the continuous projection stereolithography process.  The research revealed the underlying physics in continuous 3D printing and provided the fundamental knowledge for continuous 3D printing process planning and machine design, enabling continuous printing of objects with better surface quality, higher density, and wider solid cross-section areas, in a shorter time.       

Outcomes- Broader Impacts:

This project solved challenges in the design of a continuous 3D printing process and machine, for rapid production of arbitrary structures, not only trusses or shells, but also solid objects. Moreover, this project made an impact on training of students at UIC and the Chicago area, including minority students. Research outcomes have been integrated into the PIs' courses: “ME/IE 594 Advanced Topics in 3D Printing/ Additive Manufacturing”, “ENGR 111 Engineering Practicum in Additive Manufacturing”, and “ME211 Fluid Mechanics”.  Hands-on microfluidics teaching modules and advanced manufacturing modules were developed and evaluated to enhance the undergraduate and graduate education at UIC. Workshops and seminars were developed from this project and given at Women In Engineering Programs (WIEP), UIC Summer Engineering Camp, and high schools in Chicago area, to promote advanced manufacturing to K-12 women students, black American high school students, and other middle/high school students. Additionally, low-income undergraduate students, female students, and talented graduate students at UIC were recruited to work on this project and being trained.  The project results were disseminated widely to research communities through conferences and seminars, industrial sectors through meetings and collaborations, and the general public through lab tours and news coverages.  Two PhD students and a MS student graduated with theses developed or partially developed from this project.  Four journal papers were developed from this research and have been published. Another three journal papers were in review or in preparation.


Last Modified: 09/08/2019
Modified by: Yayue Pan
